title: 109_s1319
content: The Employee Stock Ownership Plan Promotion and Improvement Act of 2005 exempts certain S corporation distributions from a 10 percent penalty tax if they are made on stock held by an employee stock ownership plan. This amendment applies to distributions made after the enactment of the Act. ESOP dividend exception to adjustments based on adjusted current earnings. The amendment exempts ESOP dividends from certain deductions under the Internal Revenue Code, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1989. Refunds or credits resulting from this amendment may have limitations waived. Refunds or credits resulting from the amendment exempting ESOP dividends from certain deductions under the Internal Revenue Code may still be allowed within 1 year of enactment, even if prevented by law. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS RELATED TO SECTION 1042. Amendments related to Section 1042 include deferral of tax for certain sales to an employee stock ownership plan sponsored by an S Corporation and reinvestment in certain mutual funds permitted. The effective date for the tax deferral applies to sales after the enactment of the Act. Financial institutions, insurance companies, and mutual funds are included in the definition of an operating corporation. The amendment in section 581 applies to sales of qualified securities after the enactment of the Act. There is a modification to the 25-percent shareholder rule in section 409(n)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision for individuals who own more than 25 percent of the voting power or stock value of a corporation. This amendment is effective immediately. The amendment made by paragraph (1) will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Early distributions from employee stock ownership plans for higher education expenses and first-time homebuyer purchases. SEC. 5 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow distributions from employee stock ownership plans for higher education expenses and first-time homebuyer purchases. The text chunk discusses limitations on distributions from employee stock ownership plans for higher education expenses and first-time homebuyer purchases. Distributions must be reduced by certain expenses and qualified first-time homebuyer distributions to be taken into account. The distribution must be in the form of employer securities or cash proceeds. The distribution from employee stock ownership plans for higher education expenses and first-time homebuyer purchases must be in the form of employer securities or cash proceeds resulting from the sale of such securities made not more than 180 days before the distribution date. The securities distributed or sold must have been held by the plan for at least 5 years, and the total number of shares distributed or sold must be considered along with previous distributions and sales of the same securities. The distribution from employee stock ownership plans for higher education expenses and first-time homebuyer purchases must be in the form of employer securities or cash proceeds resulting from the sale of such securities made not more than 180 days before the distribution date. The securities distributed or sold must have been held by the plan for at least 5 years, and the total number of shares distributed or sold must be considered along with previous distributions and sales of the same securities. Conforming Amendments: Paragraph (7) of section 72(t) of the Code is amended by striking "paragraph (2)(E)" and inserting "subparagraphs (E) and (G) of paragraph (2)". The amendments made by this section apply to distributions made after the enactment date of the Act, specifically affecting paragraph (8) of section 72(t) of the Code by including subparagraphs (F) and (G) of paragraph (2). SEC. 6. De minimis exception to diversification of investment requirement. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a plan to exclude accounts with balances under $2,500 from certain requirements. Effective for plan years after the enactment of this Act.
